Synthetic 111111 200200200 Linear model

references:
Datasets and models. We considered different machine learning tasks on five federated benchmark datasets:
image classification (CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky, 2009)), handwritten character recognition (FEMNISTÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018)), language modeling (Shakespeare (Caldas etÂ al., 2018; McMahan etÂ al., 2017)), and logistic regression on a synthetic dataset described in AppendixÂ D.1.
TableÂ 1 summarizes datasets, models, and the total number of clients. Details on the datasets, models, and hyperparameters selection are provided in AppendixÂ D. The code is available at https://github.com/omarfoq/streaming-fl.

Main Results. TableÂ 2 reports the test accuracy when Nhist/N=20subscriptğ‘histğ‘20N_{\text{hist}}/N=20% for the different strategies together with
the optimal test accuracy obtained selecting the value of phist=âˆ‘m=1Mhistpmsubscriptğ‘histsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘€histsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šp_{\text{hist}}=\sum_{m=1}^{M_{\text{hist}}}p_{m} in the grid {0,0.2,0.5,0.8,1.0}00.20.50.81.0\{0,0.2,0.5,0.8,1.0\}. Our observations are confirmed for other values of Nhist/Nsubscriptğ‘histğ‘N_{\text{hist}}/N (see TableÂ 4 and TableÂ 5 in AppendixÂ E).
A first remark is that working only with new data (as Fresh does) is never optimal, not even when historical data account for just 555% of the total dataset (TableÂ 4). Second, neither of the two â€œreasonableâ€ ways to extend FedAvg consistently achieves good accuracy: Historical performs poorly over Synthetic and Uniform over FEMNIST and Shakespeare.
On the contrary, our method always performs at least as well as the best baseline and it often achieves a test accuracy similar to the (estimated) optimal one. In particular, it correctly sets weights as Uniform over Synthetic and as Historical over FEMNIST and Shakespeare.
We observe that our analysis also helps to explain the counter-intuitive conclusion that, on FEMNIST and Shakespeare, it is beneficial to ignore new collected samples (even for Nhist/N=5%subscriptğ‘histğ‘percent5N_{\text{hist}}/N=5\%, see TableÂ 4).
Our strategy correctly sets p^histâˆ—=1subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘hist1\hat{p}^{*}_{\text{hist}}=1, because it estimates that, for these two datasets, the ratio of the number of parameters to the aggregate training dataset size (d/Nğ‘‘ğ‘d/N) is much smaller than the gradientsâ€™ normÂ (GğºG)â€”numerical values are provided in AppendixÂ D.4. This information suggests that we can use a small subset of the original dataset to identify a good model in the selected hypotheses class, and in particular we can rely only on historical data avoiding the potential noise introduced by new samples.
